div1.head: Report "Behavior of the Heart in the Experimental Infection of Guinea Pigs and Monkeys with Leptospira icteroides and Leptospira icterhemorrhagica," by A.E. Cohn and Hideyo Noguchi, June 1921
div1.p:
Behavior of the Heart in the Experimental Infection
of Guinea Pigs and Monkeys with Leptospira icteroides
and Leptospira icterhemorrhagica.
A. E. Cohn and H. Noguchi.

The authors quote Faget and Touatre as saying that “the
rate of the heart has a tendency to slow in yellow fever” in
the first stages; and that it is slow in convalescence: & that in
fatal cases-in-the final stage--it is either rapid or slow.

That this statement of Faget's law is not absolutely cor-
rect, and that the fatal result (in man) usually occurs with a
rising pulse--not always high, but generally high in proportion
to the temperature, is a matter not affecting these experiments.

Eight guinea pigs were inoculated with Leptospira icter-
oides: One showed no effect--probably insusceptible: Of the
seven others, two--both dying--showed increase of pulse rate a-
bove that before inoculation--44 and 45 beats respectively. The
other five showed a fall of pulse rate. Four of these died: the
pulse rate of all (save one) was lowest on the day of death, the
fall varying from 33 to 130 beats. The average normal pulse of
guinea pigs was about 300 per minute.

The pulse picture of guinea pigs inoculated with Lepto-
spira icterhemorrhagica is well nigh identical with those with
which icteroides was used. Although somewhat like the pulse
picture of yellow fever in man, neither resembee it closely.

Five monkeys were inoculated, three with icteroides and
two with icterohmorrhagica. Two of them, one for each infec-
tion, failed to develope a characteristic reaction. The
other three, two with icteroides and one with icterohemorrha-
gica, showed a similar low pulse to that of the Guinea pigs.

From the electro-cardiograms, of which a number were sub-
mitted, the authors deduce that “The mechanism of slowing in
all cases until the day of death was of a simple variety--a
slowing of the whole heart, depending on the sinus, the pace-
maker of the heart. On the day of death, although increased
length of the auriculo-ventricular interval occurred, it led
to heart block only once!
